text: hello everyone thank you for joining my talk today on designing metrics programs to respect contributor expectations and
promote safety my name is Sophia Vargas for those of you I haven't met I am a researcher and program manager in
Google's open source programs office and I'm also an active member of the chaos Community which is a project that
focuses on discussing defining and building software to implement metrics
around open source projects uh specifically designed to measure health and
sustainability a little bit more about me and why I'm interested in this topic I have a background in market research
Consulting data analytics program management and when we talk about something like data collection and data
practice and data policy I want to expressly point out that I'm not a lawyer so please do not take anything in
this presentation as legal advice uh instead consider it as awareness what would I like to have known before and
acknowledgement of when you should be Consulting legal expertise in your
practice so bringing us back to the the question at hand um can we measure the
health of our projects well we can uh there are ways to collect data around our communities and if we set goals
around whatever Health means to us a growing contribution or converting more
uh intermittent contributors to full-time contributors to maintainers whatever it means to build health and sustainability in your community can we
measure that over time and track and see how we're doing but in order to measure that we have to collect data about our
community about people and often people that can choose to be anonymous people that can choose to identify who they are
in a community call with their camera off or Supply their work information the
location information in their GitHub profile so we have a whole range of information about people that we are
working with in these communities but it's not necessarily consistent so we think about collecting data in order to
measure something like project health we have to think about the individuals and the data we're collecting about them and
so how do we ensure that when we approach these types of programs we're meeting people at their own privacy
expectations in order to ensure their safety in any of the community because if you think about there are some
identifiers that are now at under attack in some communities and we would never want to put our community members in a
place where they could be subject to harm so the first question we have is
who's actually accountable for the data itself um data could be collected by
companies by projects and influenced by regulators and regionali and depending
on where you are and where you're collecting the data you might be subject to different rules and regulations um
and say I like this example in the chaos Community we've been working on the Dei
event badging program where we're encouraging events to have more diverse representation in their speaker profiles
um and so in order to do that we've asked the event leaders to share that demographic information with us as we
review it as part of this badging program but the more that we were doing this the more that we were collecting this data we recognize that well we
should actually be transparent with the community in terms of how we're using this information how we're ensuring that
their information is being used expressly for this purpose and nothing else as well as how we're protecting and
ensuring that this information is only staying with us and the trusted member of this community so we thought this was
a necessary addition to put on our public facing documentation to ensure that anyone who shared their information
with us knew what we were going to do with it and how we were going to protect it so if you are thinking about
collecting data about your community or a community that you're a member of generally the recommendation is that you
The Collector are accountable you might be working at a company you might be working for a nonprofit and yes some of
those again nuances and what's being regulated and how it's being regulated might change depending on where you work
if you just assume responsibility then you're the one who's going to be navigating this on behalf of your
community so when I think about data collection I think about it in sort of three main buckets uh we can ask people
directly who they are what they do what they're interested in what they're working on in the form of surveys and
interviews discussions and forums we can go out and scrape data that's already there through crawling websites or
pulling from platform apis like GitHub and stack Overflow and then we can kind of fill in the holes from what we know
or assume and you can see kind of sounding a little bit more skeptical here because this is never going to be something that I'm going to recommend uh
especially in the context of Community Health and metrics I will say that there are use cases that I think this is a
little bit more appropriate in say in an academic approach where we're looking at thousands of people and we're trying to
figure out how to estimate various different types of identifiers in a population in that case okay maybe
that's okay because those things that are being labeled are never coming back to the individual they're happening at
an aggregate level where those individuals yes their identity might be assumed but we're not actually labeling
them individually because it's happening at an Aggregate and systematic level but in our communities this is where things
can start to get a little sticky I might en encourage you to assume information that people don't necessarily want to share with a broader public because
they've shared it with you as a trusted member of their community and maybe they don't want you to write that down in a
place where uh they haven't agreed to that so I'm never going to recommend it in the context of gathering data about
your community and displaying it back um the other area where guessing
becomes highly problematic is that when we think about how we get consent about using this information if you are
guessing and you're not interacting with the person directly you're not actually getting consent from them versus if you go up to them and say hey are you okay
with this information being used then you've expressly gone out and asked for their uh asked for their permission to
use it in this context so again never going to recommend guessing in this context because it can encourage
inaccuracy and potentially stereotyping so if we are asking people in again form surveys interviews we can
explicitly ask for consent we can also allow for individuals to provide conditional consent say I only want my
information being used if you have at least 30 people that fall in my category because then I know that I have some
anonymity in that or maybe we offer partial ways so allowing respondents to
opt out of questions that they may or may not feel comfortable sharing with us the one challenge here is that later on
I'm going to generally my General stance is if you're running a survey it should be anonymous that can encourage more uh
reduce the fear of harm or retaliation um as well as allowing people to feel more open and honest because they know
it's not coming back to them however this does present a challenge uh in terms of say being able to withdraw our
alter submission because if it's truly Anonymous you you can't actually retract it anymore because there's no way for me
to find which one is yours so in theory you could say add an identifier for surveys but by some regular ation
approaches this is not Anonymous anymore because people can be reidentified by those values when we're scraping data that's
already there I would say the general recommendation is as long as you were following following all the existing
platform policies around data use and data use case then you're essentially writing on the implicit consent that's
already been granted by the platform if you sign up for GitHub you say I yes I agree to your terms of service so now
that I'm pulling data from GitHub I want to ensure that I am actually following those terms of service say I'm not using
your email to send out marketing content because that is explicitly prohibited in github's terms of service and data
policies so as long as you know what those policies are and you comply with them then you can essentially borrow
that consent that's already been given to the platform which has also allowed individuals to only share information
conditionally say there there's some information that's only shared with org members or some details about interactions that are only going to the
org members um and some information you don't have to necessarily volunteer you don't have to put your name you don't
have to put your geography you don't have to put your company on GitHub so there is an element of allowing individuals to share as much information
as they want to on that platform where this breaks down and gets more ambiguous is that when we start to
aggregate data across platforms because there is no mechanism to allow for consent to aggregate this into yet a new
data set that will have net new information in it um I had an example in here earlier just because I was trying
to cut down time but if you look me up on GitHub you can see where I work you can see where I live and generally
that's enough information to find me on LinkedIn and see where I worked before see where I went to college and at a
certain point now you're aggregating a lot more information about me in one place that I haven't necessarily
expressly given permission to so this is a case where if you are planning to do this it's a good idea to bring it to
your project leadership and your board and discuss your approach first what you want to do with it why you want to use this information and to give the
community an opportunity to provide feedback and or opt in or out of this so a little bit more about survey
sampling and here here's where I'm putting back my my market research hat on um if you've ever run a large and
comprehensive study uh the thing that really qualifies what we can do with the data is the sample size how many people
did we get and what portion of the thing we wanted who do we want to know about is represented in that sample um and
typically this allows you to say understand how you can extrapolate the data so say the US Census has
information about all of all the people who live in the United States well that supply that information but it's a
massive portion that they can kind of extrapolate what's happening in the broader Community because they know they have representative sample but in our
communities we often don't know how many people are there or present at any given moment in time so it gets a little bit
fuzzier when we think about open source communities because we might not really know we might think we have the majority but we might not um and so just think
about that in terms of what it actually means how you present the data what things you can conjecture based on that
data and recognizing that it's always going to have some sort of inherent bias it is incredibly difficult to remove
bias from a survey because at a certain point I'm only say recruiting participants of the kubernetes community
that's just one Community that's not everyone and so we're inherently narrowing it down to the populations we
want to talk to but I say if we only recruit on a platform like slack then we're also limiting who we talk to and
recognizing that where we recruit is also going to affect who actually is exposed to this who can take the study
and again acknowledge who you're able to include in this type of exercise um and
generally respecting the Norms there are some channels that are not meant to be recruited from say if it's a channel dedicated to something like issue triage
they probably wouldn't appreciate having a survey placed in there that's not about issue triage um generally Market researchers
have lower limits that they are more or less comfortable with talking to represent data in uh percentage forms
and from a conservative sense this would be a sample size of 50 people um a less conservative sense maybe it'll go down
to 30 but below that is when the numbers sort of start to break down because representing it as a percentage starts
to become more misleading and you might start to be able to figure out who people are based on how they respond
just the smaller and smaller the sample gets um the challenge is yes you might not have 30 people in your community
that's actually quite larger large number for some open source projects so it's just an acknowledgement that you
might not be able to present the data in the same way and it's going to take a lot more care and consideration and how
you present your findings to acknowledge that you're not actually inadvertently exposing someone who thought they were
Anonymous um to build on some of the other best practices around surveys for questions please only ask what you
really need to know um it's really easy as a researcher to just kind of keep shoving in more questions because
wouldn't it be nice to know that um but it's just going to make things longer and the longer they get the more likely people will bail um so generally don't
exceed 10 minutes I know I wrote 25 and 15 here because that's usually again what Market researchers say but I think
that's still too long the shorter the survey the more likely people will finish it in addition to that it's
really easy to ask for too much information than you actually need so one example that came up recently in my world was asking where people lived
which is a sensitive and protected category and when I dug into it with the project leaders the things we really
wanted to know were what languages are people working in so we can prioritize translation okay that's a different
question or what time zone should we be prioritizing for meetings so maybe asking what time zone you like to work
in which may or may not correlate to your geography and what language is your primary working language or do you feel
comfortable working in um those were much more pointed much more to the point much more actionable um than asking for
something like geography which is a lot more sensitive and potentially not even get to the things that you need um limiting open-ended questions
it's really easy to slide in a few more extraneous details that can expose who you are so it's helpful to remind
participants to talk in generalities and again you as the data owner are accountable for ensuring that you redact
anything that someone has said that might help re-identify them um brackets and buckets can help to make things more
General so something like a category like age instead of asking for someone's age ask for someone's age in buckets um
and this way you're reducing specificity while still providing the analyst some things to run distributions and
analytics on um in very small populations you might want to group more things together especially things like
underrepresented groups which yes that might limit your analysis potential but if you only have two or three people
identifying in these different under underrepresented groups that's not a large enough sample to really learn from
so you can talk about these things in general but then maybe if you only get a handful of folks at the backend if you're going to display the data group
it together and that way again people's uh identities are a little bit more protected allow people to opt out of
anything that is sensitive uh say potentially all demographic questions um and where all possible borrow from
existing lists um I've written I don't know hundreds of surveys and I still
struggle to say comprehensively list out all the various different types of titles someone can have in a technical
profession it can be massive and if you want to keep your list to like say 13 to 14 which is sort of that like standard
size of a survey question um it can be really hard to do that and so just look at another survey see how someone else
has done it it's much easier to react to a list and make it better and fit your case than it is to write a list in
general um and this can get even more problematic when we start to think about again those sensitive demographic questions um so here I'm recommending
looking at the the open demographics project that has been crowdsourcing how we provide a comprehensive set of
categories around demographic and identifiers so these can be really helpful places to start by looking at existing studies as well as um looking
at projects that are focused on this specifically in interviews uh most of
the time these are definitely not Anonymous they are people talking to people um so then again it's on the data
collector to ensure they're redacting and abstracting away any of the details so typically again you can ask
participants how much about themselves are willing to share but you can also just fully abstract that in your findings participant X said that and if
you want to include more information about who you spoke with then maybe you have a table that says I talked to 10 people and five of them came from large
tech companies and five of them came from these different particular regions but because that's separated from your
interview cat like participant XYZ then there's no connection back to those identities um typically in larger
studies we'll see an abstraction like job title and a role in Industry so I might be a program manager at a large
tech company and I'm okay with that identifier because there are thousands of us at Google so I'm I'm not really
inadvertently exposing Myself by by referring to myself in this category however if I said program manager at
Google and we knew it was an interview from say chaos participants you know
exactly who I am now so acknowledging who is who is present in this study who
is present in this space um what lists are public can help you identify how
best to abstract this and if you're concern ered at all again just revert back to full
abstraction uh a little bit more about passive data collection so again pulling from existing information sources you
have to acknowledge that there isn't always a place to opt out um if your platform sorry if your codebase lives on
GitHub then your participants have to opt into GitHub in order to participate um and so there might be areas where
you're now starting to aggregate information that may or may not be identifiable because you know your community members um so again this is an
opportunity to bring this back to the community to acknowledge what you're doing and what you're trying to do with it and allow for feedback on how this
information is being portrayed um a lot of things are outdated on GitHub I just acknowledge people don't go in and
change things immediately so if you're looking at prior historical logs they may or may not be showing accurate
information and there's always going to be information that's missing because again you didn't go out and ask people directly one of my favorite examples is
there's a lot of effort to assume what company you work for based on the domain of your email say the def stat project
does this and it is helpful to know where people are coming from but we don't know if people that are
identifying as working at Google are actively doing this work during their time at Google a lot of people are
actively volunteering in these spaces and might identify that they work at a company but that doesn't actually mean that they're doing this work on behalf
of their company and so there's a lot of nuance that's lacking from these platforms and that's just again information that you have to go directly
to the community members and ask them if that's something that you need know and we already mentioned it but being
consider across uh consider it with crossplatform data aggregation now I want to spend a little
bit of time talking about another program in the chaos project which I've mentioned a few times stands for
Community Health analytics and of Open Source software so again we think about metrics we design metrics we build
software to collect these metrics um we launched another program last year where I already talked about the event pading
program we have now the Dei project badging pilot which is a way for projects to highlight the efforts that
they're taking to promote diversity Equity inclusion in their communities and the reason why I wanted to bring it
up in this context is when we think about measuring something like how we're doing in Dei we often revert back to
representation and identifiers in our community and everything we've talked to about today acknowledges that these are
highly sensitive and protected pieces of information and in fact pieces of information that could cause harm depending on where you live in this
country um and so it might not be prudent for you to go out and collect this especially if your community is
small and so what I what I like about this program is instead of looking at metrics or presenting metrics that look
at representation in actuality instead they encourage projects to write intentionally how they plan to work on
things like project accessibility or commun communication transparency what they're doing to welcome newcomers and
provide an accessible experience for newcomers and how they're thinking about increasing diversity in their leadership
which is the most visible part of that community and these are things that projects can report on create metrics to
measure against and that have nothing to do with collecting protected information categories from their Community um so I
really like this as an approach for particularly small communities or ones where you're sensitive about collecting this information and again if you have a
community of two people you're probably not diverse because they're just two of you and you can't really be diverse with
two people and that's okay but you still have an opportunity to say hey I want to make sure that my project is friendly
and welcoming to people that may or may not look like me or identify with the things that that I
represent so with all these things in mind um I think mostly we want to take a step back and ensure that we choose the
methodology that not only meets our goals but fits the shape of our
community so some general principles um we've mentioned this a few times but where and all possible preserve
anonymity this can really help to encourage honesty and again reduce that harm a fear of retaliation
um we already mentioned this already in terms of the accountability piece but really try to limit access to the raw
data because typically the raw data is going to be the identifiable data again even in Anonymous survey if you only get
six people filling out your form you might be able to figure out who those six people are based on how they responded to things so you as the data
owner collector analyst are responsible for ensuring that the way that you portray this information again respects
that privacy and anonymity um that was uh presented at at the front of this
program um you can use a third party to help remove and reduce risk here but it's generally not something I going to
recommend because this costs money and these people don't have any context about your community and may not be able
to know how to interpret the results in a way that's helpful and relevant um you can also try just limiting your
retention period if you finish your analysis project delete the data which can sometimes be a little bit scary
because you're like but what if I want to go look at this thing and you're like well okay maybe after a year we throw it
out because then we're going to run it again we'll have a whole new data so save your aggregate results but don't keep limit the retention period and
again it might be uncomfortable but the longer these things stick around the longer that they might get shared to more and more people that may or may not
respect the intentions that were initially aligned outlined for this project um reviewing and complying with
all applicable policies um there are many policies that should be considered here not only happening at the foundation and the community level but
the platform level and again if you're a company then the company level or any regionality that you're subject to it's
always the best practice to have somebody else look at what you're doing so auditing reviewing and testing your
methodology um can come from your project leadership and community members if you're doing this on behalf of a
research institution then you can lean on your International in sorry institutional review board um and again
Consulting legal and privacy experts when applicable and always communicate what
you're trying to do how you tend to use this information what you're expecting to do with it um and what measures
you're going to take to ensure the privacy and protection of all those who participate I want to close with some
general considerations um typically 100% participation is never going to happen
um and that's okay um I think in most surveys like if I get 10% of my population responding or my Outreach
list that's actually pretty good um so again it's expect expect less uh and
when you get data be thankful for that data but then also recognize what and who is potentially missing from this
sample um you're never really going to collect everything so what does that mean about what you can infer again
thinking again about that initial recommendation of understanding the sample you collect and how is representative or not of the community
um and remembering that no data is data uh and that if you don't collect any information about some folks that could
mean that yes maybe they're not present or two maybe they didn't feel comfortable sharing and maybe that's something else that you're it's willing
to explore and understand why why or why not uh this information is being exposed in in this collection practice
um always recognizing that externalities might impact your results so you probably don't want to run a survey
during a release uh it's it seems simple but I've seen it happen don't do that uh
people are busy already and your people are your most valuable resource be respectful of their time um and
acknowledge and and figure out what Cadence makes the most sense for your community um and please don't overs
survey um I say personally had four surveys in my inbox this month that is
too many uh and so only pick and choose the ones that I either have to take or
that I want to take um and so again be respectful of your community members time um and maybe only do this once a
year unless there's a really really good use case um for additional thoughts and best practices around data collection
and research in open source communities um I'm referring to a piece of research that was published last year by a couple
of fellow researchers and colleagues um around best practices for open source ecosystem
researchers want to close with the fact that data is a tool it is not innately good or bad um
and it can be used for both positive and negative things so you again have to
resume the responsibility to use data wisely um and so kind of the general principles I like are being incredibly
deliberate data is a tool that can be used to elicit a change can be alluded to is a change in Behavior but is it the
behavioral change that you wanted to encourage my favorite example here are leaderboards I know I've heard a lot
about death stats uh this past week and I I love the project I love what it's uh allowing the broader Community to track
and to be visible of but it does also encourage some behaviors by saying this is how we create um our nominations list
for our leadership by how these contributions are appearing in in this particular aggregation tool and so
you're essentially encouraging people to ensure that they have the right and highest level of stats in order to do
that and those may or may not be the things that are really needed in the community so when we do display a
leaderboard is that again is that the behavior that we want to change or maybe we don't necessarily want to always show
all things to all people because sometimes your community leadership needs to no information but it isn't
necessarily helpful to show it to the broader community so being really deliberate about what we show to whom
that can really again elicit the change that we want and the behavior that we want to influence in the community
without again encouraging un wanted or changes in behavior that weren't intended um and it's really easy to
cherry-pick data pull it out of context use it however you want I've seen this happen numerous amounts of time um and
so try to to fight against that by always including your bases your sources
your methodology how sample was collected when it was collected and having sort of a referenceable
information sheet around your data don't release data without this please ever um people can understand where where it
came from how to understand how to interpret it because even if you you're taking those things into consideration having I as a as a researcher I always
look for it before I interpret any data I want to know how many people were present how people were participating in
it how they were allowed to participate in it when it was collected these are all the things that help me understand what I'm looking at and how to interpret
the results um not everyone will do this so please include it on one place to again not leave room for
misinterpretation um thank you that's it um I actually cut this down lot it may be too much but I I actually don't mind
